unless otherwise noted, all figures in this emodule are from grays anatomy for students, 3e, by drake , vogl, & mitchell, 2015 by elsevier. this is a recommended resource. click to continue click to continue click to continue emodule tutorial emodule tutorial emodule tutorial

the skeleton is quite sensibly divided into an axial division and an appendicular division. the axial division consists of the skull, vertebral column and bony thorax. in unit 1, you were introduced to the vertebral column and bony thorax. in unit 2, you learned the anatomy of the skull. in unit 3, you studied the appendicular division of the skeleton, including the pectoral girdle and upper limb, and the pelvic girdle and lower limb. in addition, you learned the fascial compartments of the limbs and the peripheral vascular system. now, in cpc-2, unit 5, you will learn the anatomy of the musculoskeletal system, including the articulations , movements, major muscles and nerves of the limbs. unit 5 overview previous next

prior to lab 14, complete exercise 14a, a short self-learning module that teaches you the nomenclature of movement and 14b, a short self-learning module that teaches you about the basic structure of articulations and entheses. the lab will begin with an ap-based quiz on these slms. lab 14 includes four exercises that describe the proximal articulations and musculature of the limbs. prior to the lab, you must review the content of exercises 14.1 - 14.4 so that your time in lab is used efficiently. the material for these exercises will be placed at four different stations around your lab room. you will work and rotate with your pairs: 14.5 is a review exercise on the vertebral column, focusing on its articulations. in week 39, you will learn about back pain, and it is important for this anatomy to be fresh in your mind. the material for 14.5 will be at the side table in your lab. go through this exercise when you finish a station early. it is examinable. 14.6 is a field trip to grants museum, where there are outstanding dissections of musculoskeletal anatomy, including the deep musculature of the back. take time to study these specimens. lab 14 instructions previous take me to exercise selection exercise 9:00-10:30 10:30-12:00 12:00-1:00 1:00-2:30 2:30-4:00 14.1 pairs 1 pairs 4 lunch pairs 3 pairs 2 14.2 pairs 2 pairs 1 lunch pairs 4 pairs 3 14.3 pairs 3 pairs 2 lunch pairs 1 pairs 4 14.4 pairs 4 pairs 3 lunch pairs 2 pairs 1

using the emodule use this emodule before labs to prepare for them, during labs to guide your studies, and after labs as a review tool. to complete each section, use the next button at the bottom of the pages, swipe next, or press the right arrow key to move forward one page at a time. use the menu, available by clicking menu at the top, to navigate to specific slides. use search to quickly find instances of relevant terms. use the previous button at the bottom of the pages, swipe previous or press the left arrow key to move back one page at a time. lab 14 14a prelab slm 14b prelab slm 14.1 the shoulder previous next

previous got it, lets move on conventions used in the emodule tasks, introduced on a pink bar and continued below the bar in bold, are actions that you should take to help you understand the content: and how the superior and inferior articular facets of adjacent vertebrae articulate with one another. note how they fit together, tas k with age, wear and tear, info an intervertebral disc can herniate, such that the nucleus pulposus. information that has implications for health and disease is introduced on a blue bar and continued below the bar: the film button appears on the bottom bar of slides where a video accompanies tasks or explanations. the photo button appears at the bottom of slides where a photo accompanies tasks. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to jump to related content. click the icon to jump back. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to see a definition. words / phrases in purple denote concepts with which you should become familiar. the slide talk icon appears on the top bar of slides containing a recording of me explaining concepts.

14a nomenclature of movement objectives: when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: understand, and use properly, the nomenclature of relative position and planes of section understand, and use properly, the nomenclature describing movement next back to exercise selection

2 it is important to know, and use properly, the language that describes movement in order to be able to communicate clearly with colleagues regarding patients. this avoids misunderstanding, improves care, and keeps patients safe. this slm describes this language, which will be used not only throughout the anatomy lessons contained in unit 5, but by clinician teachers during your training and beyond; i.e. by colleagues throughout your career. well start by recapping the basic anatomical nomenclature described in unit 1. then, the nomenclature specific to the limbs is described. 14a introduction previous next

the position of structures is described with the body in the anatomical position: erect posture, feet together, eyes forward, palms forward. terms are usually* relative anterior in front of vs. posterior behind, as compared to : ventral toward the belly vs. dorsal toward the back superior above vs. inferior below cranial / cephalic toward the head vs. caudal toward the tail (i.e. the coccyx in humans) medial toward the midline vs. lateral away from the midline median* is an absolute term proximal toward the beginning vs. distal toward the end re. limbs; also tubular structures such as the digestive and genitourinary systems superficial toward the surface vs. deep away from the surface 14a anatomical position & directional nomenclature next previous 3

14a sectional nomenclature sagittal plane separates the body into right and left portions. a midsagittal section passes through the midline, dividing the body into right and left halves . a parasagittal section misses the midline, creating right and left portions of unequal size . the sagittal plane is oriented parallel to the long axis of the body. sectioning produces a 2d representation of a 3d structure. it shows only the structures that are in the plane of section. structures outside the plane of section are not seen. frontal or coronal plane separates the body into anterior and posterior portions. the coronal plane is oriented parallel to the long axis of the body. transverse or cross-sectional plane separates the body into superior and inferior portions. the transverse plane is oriented perpendicular to the long axis of the body. in humans, it is equivalent to the horizontal plane. 4 next previous

14a nomenclature of movement movement between two or more bones occurs at joints. the starting point for these descriptions is taken to be the anatomical position. linear motion occurs when bones translate relative to each other, a movement that is often described as gliding; e.g. gliding occurs between the carpal bones of our wrists. angular motion occurs when the angle between two bones changes. flexion and extension are antagonistic movements that occur in the sagittal plane, therefore moving a body part anteriorly or posteriorly. flexion decreases the angle between articulating elements, extension increases the angle between articulating elements . there is one exception to this definition . abduction and adduction are antagonistic movements that occur in the coronal plane, relative to the midline of the body. abduction is a movement away from the midline, adduction is a movement toward the midline. abduction and adduction occur at the shoulder and hip, for example, when we do jumping jacks . rotation occurs around the long axis of a bone or structure. medial and lateral rotation occur in the limbs when we rotate them inward, toward the midline and outward, away from the midline, respectively. medial and lateral rotation occur at the shoulder and hip, for example . left / right rotation occurs with rotation of the vertebral column around its long axis . 5 next previous

14a special anatomical terms of movement elevation and depression are movements up and down, respectively. they occur at the temporomandibular joint (tmj) when we chew, and between the scapula and thorax when we shrug our shoulders. protraction and retraction are movements forward and backward, respectively. they occur at the tmj when we jut our jaw outward and then pull it backward, and between the scapula and thorax when we row a boat . pronation and supination are special terms used to describe the rotation of the forearm around its long axis. starting in anatomical position, rotation of the forearm such that the palm is facing backward is pronation. rotation of the forearm such that the palm is facing forward is supination. thus, in anatomical position, the forearm is supinated . opposition touches the pads of the thumb and a finger together. reposition returns them to the anatomical position. lateral flexion or lateral bending is a movement specific to the vertebral column, in which we bend from side to side, as in sliding our hand down the lateral aspect of the leg . dorsiflexion and plantarflexion are movements specific to the talocrural (or ankle) joint, in which the foot is turned upward and downward, respectively. plantarflexion of the talocrural joint permits you to point your toes . eversion and inversion are movements specific to the foot, in which we turn the sole of the foot outward (as in toward a side wall) and inward (as in toward the other foot), respectively . 6 previous next
youve reached the end of this exercise. do you want to take the slm 14a quiz ? 7 previous 14a quiz start oh, yeah! go to the quiz im disappointed, ann. i thought we could be friends. skip the quiz
congratulations on finishing slm 14a! back to exercise selection back to exercise selection back to exercise selection review 14a review 14a review 14a previous

14b articulations and entheses objectives: when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: describe the different classes of articulations in the body describe the defining structure of a synovial joint describe the various accessory structures that may be present in a synovial joint describe entheses and explain their importance in tendon attachment next back to exercise selection

14b structural classes of joints articulations occur wherever two bones meet. movement occurs at articulations; however, not all articulations permit movement. joints are classified as synovial joints if the two articulating surfaces are separated by a fluid-filled articular cavity. these are the most mobile joints. joints are classified as solid joints if the two bones are joined by ct. some solid joints permit no movement, while others permit limited movement. 2 previous next

14b solid joints may be bony, fibrous or cartilaginous in a synostosis , two bones fuse, as occurs with the normal maturation of the frontal or occipital bone, or the development of irregular bones such as the vertebrae or ossa coxae. in a fibrous synarthrosis , two bones are joined by fibrous ct. examples are the sutures joining the flat bones of the skull and the gomphoses that hold teeth in their bony sockets, which are both immoveable joints. in a syndesmosis, two bones are joined by a sheet of dense irregular ct; examples are the interosseous membranes between the radius and ulna, and between the tibia and fibula. in a cartilaginous synarthrosis, two bones are jointed by cartilage. a synchondrosis is immoveable; an example is the epiphyseal plate of a growing bone. a symphysis permits some movement; examples are the intervertebral discs and the pubic symphysis. 3 previous next

a dense, irregular ct joint capsule encloses the articulating elements, isolating the articular cavity. a ligament, by definition, connects bone to bone. intrinsic ligaments (not shown) reinforce the fibrous joint capsule along stress lines. structurally, they are regions of the joint capsule where the collagen fibres become more regular and the capsule thicker. to be clear, they are not structures separate from the joint capsule, but simply regions of the capsule that are more robust. they strengthen the joint capsule along the lines where tensile forces are greatest, and resist tearing of the capsule in response to applied forces . the contained articulating surfaces of the bones are covered with hyaline (articular) cartilage, which creates smooth articular surfaces. cartilage loss occurs in osteoarthritis . 14b synovial joints 4 previous next there is ct between the joint capsule and its inner lining of synovial membrane; there is no space, as is illustrated in this diagram. * diarthroses, or synovial joints, are freely moveable. synovial joints are common in the limbs. a synovial joint has a number of defining characteristics:

14b synovial membrane all other intra-articular surfaces are covered with synovial membrane, including the internal surface of the joint capsule and all the non-articular bony surfaces. synovial membrane consists of a discontinuous, simple epithelium on a vascular lamina propria. it secretes synovial fluid into the articular cavity, which i) acts as a lubricant, facilitating the movement of the articular surfaces relative to each other, and ii) also acts as a medium for molecular transfer between blood in the vessels of the lamina propria of the synovial membrane, and the chondrocytes within the avascular articular cartilages. 5 previous next there is ct between the joint capsule and its inner lining of synovial membrane; there is no space, as is illustrated in this diagram. *

14b articular discs and fat pads 6 previous next some (but not all!) synovial joints have structural modifications that affect joint function. articular discs or menisci are fibrocartilagenous wedges that are interposed between the articulating surfaces, preventing them from directly touching. fibrocartilage is stronger than articular (hyaline) cartilage; it resists greater forces, both compressive and tensile. menisci improve the fit between articulating elements. menisci are present, for instance, in the knee joint. fat pads may be present within the joint capsule, but outside its synovial membrane lining, as illustrated. fat forms an ideal packing material in joints; it is malleable and therefore changes shape to accommodate joint movement. the knee, again, has large fat pads associated with it.

14b bursae, extrinsic ligaments and tendons bursae are sacs composed of synovial membrane that contain a capillary-layer of synovial fluid. they decrease friction between structures that would otherwise rub against each other, causing tissue inflammation. subcutaneous bursae prevent skin from rubbing against bony protuberances, such as at the tip of the elbow. subtendinous bursae prevent tendons from rubbing against bone. modified bursae form synovial tendon sheaths that enclose tendons, for instance, in the hand. extrinsic ligaments (not illustrated) are dense, regular ct bands or cords that attach one bone to another across an articulation. like intrinsic ligaments, they are positioned so as to resist tensile forces that might otherwise cause joint damage, but unlike intrinsic ligaments, they are separate from the joint capsule. extrinsic ligaments are present in the shoulder joint and knee joint, for example. 7 previous next tendons are dense, regular ct bands or cords that cross a joint to attach a muscle to a bone. they move the joint with contraction of the muscle. they can be considered accessory structures of the joint because they reinforce the aspect of the joint they cross. examples are the tendons of the rotator cuff muscles that reinforce the shoulder joint.

14b stability vs. mobility joint stability is inversely proportional to joint mobility. the more mobile a joint is, the more prone it is to injuries, including dislocation. an example is the shoulder joint, which is both the most mobile joint in the body as well as the most commonly dislocated. in contrast, the sutures between the cranial bones allow no movement, and are extremely stable. stability /mobility is influenced by many factors: the shape of the articulating surfaces: if the two articulating surfaces are closely matched, joint mobility will be limited, but joint stability will be enhanced. an example is the elbow joint, as you will see. if the two articulating surfaces are poorly matched, as is the case with the shoulder joint, mobility will be enhanced, at the expense of joint stability. the structure of the joint capsule: a loose joint capsule increases joint mobility, but cannot protect against dislocation. a tight joint capsule helps to keep the articulating surfaces aligned, but will limit mobility. the strength and location of ligaments crossing a joint: ligaments resist tensile forces and help maintain joint alignment, but limit both the direction and extent of movement permitted. the tone of surrounding muscles reinforces a joint because its tendon can better resist tensile forces applied parallel to it. other tissues around a joint can limit movement. an extreme example is the presence of ribs associated with the thoracic region of the vertebral column, which contribute to making this its least mobile region. the vertebral region with the most mobility is the cervical region, which is also the region with the least amount of surrounding tissues. 8 previous next

14b functional classes of synovial joints gliding joints permit translation, or linear motion, only. they are present, for instance, between the carpal bones of the wrist. 9 previous next biaxial joints permits movement around two axes, and is therefore associated with two movement pairs: flexion / extension and abduction / adduction. biaxial joints may be i) ellipsoidal (condyloid) joints, such as the wrist (a) and knuckles or ii) saddle joints, such as is present at the base of the thumb (e). triaxial joints permits movement around three axes, and therefore is associated with three movement pairs: flexion / extension, abduction / adduction and medial / lateral rotation. triaxial joints are ball-and-socket joints, such as the shoulder and hip (d). uniaxial joints permits movement around one axis, and therefore is associated with only one movement pair. these may be i) hinge joints, such as the elbow (c), which permit only flexion and extension, or ii) pivot joints, such as is present between the axis (c2 vertebra) and atlas (c1 vertebra), which permit rotation (f).

14b entheses an enthesis is the area of attachment between tendon, ligament or joint capsule to bone. it functions to pass tensile forces from the soft tissue structure to bone, and distribute force through the bone, away from the point of attachment. this spares the point of attachment from bearing all applied forces. two types of entheses are described: fibrous and fibrocartilagenous. in fibrous (indirect) entheses, attachment occurs via periosteum with the mineralization of perforating collagen fibres. fibrous entheses tend to occur where tendon attaches to the shaft of a bone, and therefore the angle between the tendon and bone does not change during contraction of the muscle. they are less prone to stress injuries. an example is the attachment of the deltoid muscle to the midshaft of the humerus. in fibrocartilaginous (direct) entheses, attachment occurs via a transitional, fibrocartilagenous zone. they tend to occur at epiphyses or apophyses (tubercles) where the angle of attachment of the tendon to bone changes during muscular contraction. this puts stress on the enthesis. however, with normal use, the fibrocartilagenous intermediate zone permits some give, which allows the enthesis to accommodate the changing angle between the tendon and its insertion. examples of fibrocartilaginous entheses are the attachment of the rotator cuff muscles and that of the tendo calcaneus . the majority of entheses are fibrocartilaginous; they are also more prone to overuse injuries than are fibrous entheses. 10 previous next

14b four zones of a fibrocartilaginous enthesis are recognized 1) the dense regular ct of the tendon 2) an avascular fibrocartilagenous zone; the inherent strength and pliability of fibrocartilage gives this type of enthesis the ability to accommodate the change in angle between the dense regular ct of the tendon and the relative rigidity of bone that occurs with movement of the joint. the tidemark is the boundary between the uncalcified fibrocartilage and calcified fibrocartilage. mechanically-speaking, it is the border between soft and hard tissues. this boundary is relatively flat. 11 previous next 3) an avascular calcified fibrocartilagenous zone that forms a highly irregular border with the underlying bone tissue. the interlocking nature of the boundary between these two tissues provides mechanical integrity to the enthesis. 4) bone tissue. see these illustrated again here:

youve reached the end of this exercise. do you want to take the exercise 14b quiz? previous 12 14b quiz start oh, yeah! go to the quiz im disappointed, ann. i thought we could be friends. skip the quiz

14.3 the hip and knee joints back to exercise selection resources hanging skeleton articulated bony lower limb lower limb bone box a pelvis model, a pelvis model with viscera a model of the hip joint and a model of the knee joint a prosected closed hip joint and a prosected opened hip joint a prosected knee joint with ligaments and a prosected knee joint with sagittally-sectioned femur next

14.3 the hip joint: objectives 2 when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to recognize and describe the: bony and soft tissue components of the hip joint movements permitted at the hip joint bony and soft tissue components of the knee joint movements permitted at the knee joint previous next

14.3 movement pairs of the hip the hip joint is a triaxial, ball and socket joint. as such, it permits three movement pairs: flexion / extension abduction / adduction medial / lateral rotation. stand up and carry out these movements with your lab group. ensure that every member is crystal clear on what each of these movement are. this is critical to your ability to understand the relationship between the orientation of a muscle relative to the joint and its action at the joint. this approach will allow you to ultimately understand muscle action, rather than memorizing it! 3 previous next

14.3 the hip bone i the hip joint is an articulation between the acetabulum of the hip bone and the head of the femur. you learned the features of these bones in unit 3. you now have an opportunity to refresh your memory. 4 previous next identify: tas k on the hip bone available to you, ensure that you can identify the following features (if you dont know the answer to every question posed, review exercise 7.1 or discuss it with your group - there is wisdom in numbers!). its three divisions, the ilium, ischium and pubis the acetabulum, its lunate surface, the acetabular notch and acetabular fossa obturator foramen what is the obturator membrane and obturator canal? the anterior superior iliac spine and pubic tubercle what ligament joins these two bony features? in anatomical position, how are these two features oriented relative to each other? iliac crest what two bony features define the anterior and posterior limits of the iliac crest? anterior inferior iliac spine (aiis) and posterior inferior iliac spine (piis)

14.3 the hip bone ii 5 previous next identify tas k on the hip bone available to you, the following features (if you dont know the answer to a question, review exercise 7.1 or discuss it with your group - there is wisdom in numbers!). ischial spine, ischial tuberosity, greater sciatic notch, lesser sciatic notch conjoint ramus, consisting of the ischial ramus and the inferior pubic ramus body of the pubis, pubic crest and tubercle, superior pubic ramus, symphyseal surface (see diagram)name the articulation between the two hip bones at their symphyseal surfaces. gluteal surface and iliac fossa auricular surface what articulates here? what joint is formed? arcuate and pectineal lines, which contribute to the pelvic brim, and help define the pelvic inlet, which is the border between the false and true pelvises the pubic bone and pubic symphysis

14.3 the proximal femur 6 previous next articulate the head of the femur with the acetabulum of the hip bone. tas k move the articulation thus formed through its three movement pairs: flexion / extension, abduction / adduction and medial / lateral rotation (see diagram). identify the following features of the proximal femur: tas k head, fovea and neck greater trochanter and lesser trochanter, both traction epiphyses formed by the pull of muscles that attach here. intertrochanteric line and intertrochanteric crest linea aspera notice that the region of the femoral head that is in contact with the lunate surface of the acetabulum changes with these movements. medial and lateral rotation
14.3 test yourself! ap hip x-ray 7 previous next identify tas k can you identify all of the structures indicated by leaders in this ap x-ray image? orthopedicgallery.com a b c d e f g h show answers

14.3 ligaments of the pelvis sacrospinous ligaments. 8 previous next identify the sacrotuberous and tas k identify the greater and lesser sciatic foramina. identify the obturator membrane. identify the inguinal ligament. notice the gap between the inguinal ligament and the hip bone. muscles, nerves, blood vessels and lymphatics pass between the abdomen / pelvis and the anterior thigh through this gap. using the model pelvis with viscera,

14.3 foramina of the pelvis the obturator canal, which joins the pelvis and medial thigh the gap between the inguinal ligament and the pelvic bone, which joins the abdomen / pelvis with the anterior thigh the greater sciatic foramen, which joins the pelvis with the gluteal region the lesser sciatic foramen, which joins the gluteal region with the perineum 9 previous next identify tas k the various passages between the pelvis and lower limb, through which muscles, vessels and nerves pass between the pelvis and the thigh:

14.3 the capsule of the hip joint identify the articular capsule (a), a dense irregular ct capsule that encloses the joint. note that it extends from the margin of the acetabulum to enclose the femoral head and much of the femoral neck. 10 previous next a. the capsule of the hip joint extends to the intertrochanteric line, anteriorly. b, c. the intrinsic ligaments of the capsule spiral from posterior to anterior. unwrap the specimen of the closed hip joint. tas k in certain regions, the collagen fibres of the joint capsule become more regular and the capsule thicker. these are the intrinsic ligaments of the joint capsule. they are illustrated on the hip joint model. you are not responsible for identifying the individual ligaments on the prosection. know that they reinforce the joint capsule along stress lines.

14.3 intrinsic ligaments of the hip joint anatomical neck of the femur to their points of attachment. gently, move the femur slightly through flexion and extension. notice that with flexion, the ligaments become loose, but with extension, they become tight. 11 previous next notice on the prosection that the fibres of these ligaments spiral anteriorly around the tas k a. the capsule of the hip joint extends to the intertrochanteric line, anteriorly. b, c. the intrinsic ligaments of the capsule spiral from posterior to anterior. move the femur through abduction and adduction. notice that with adduction, the ligaments becomes loose, but with abduction, they becomes tight. therefore, extension and abduction are limited by the joint capsule and its intrinsic ligaments. moisten and rewrap the specimen.

14.3 internal features of the hip joint 12 previous next identify the acetabular tas k notice that it deepens the socket for articulation with the femoral head, thus increasing the congruity between the articulating elements and stabilizing the joint. the acetabular labrum is also illustrated on the hip joint model. touch the femoral head and tas k labrum, a fibrocartilagenous ring that surrounds the acetabular margin. the lunate surface of the acetabulum, the articulating surfaces of the hip joint. notice how smooth and slippery they are. what tissue covers these surfaces? identify the transverse acetabular ligament, which spans the acetabular notch and creates tas k the acetabular foramen. identify the ligament of the head of the femur, which extends from the acetabular foramen to the fovea of the femur. it contains the artery of the ligament of the head, a branch of the obturator artery that supplied blood to the head of the developing femur. this ligament is not important in stabilizing the joint; it simply acted as a conduit for these vessels. unwrap the specimen labelled open hip joint.

14.3 synovial membrane of the hip joint which lines the internal surface of the joint capsule, as well as the anatomical neck of the femur. deep to the synovial membrane on the anatomical neck, blood vessels ascend to the head of the femur. 13 previous next synovial membrane covers all non-articular surfaces within a synovial joint, including the internal surface of the fibrous joint capsule. the capsule of the hip joint is loose, which is one of the reasons that the hip joint is so mobile. therefore, synovial membrane extends from the periphery of the head of the femur, down its neck, and then reflects off the neck of the femur to cover the internal surface of the joint capsule as far as to the margin of the acetabulum. identify the synovial membrane, tas k

14.3 blood supply to the hip joint in most adults, the blood supply to the head of the femur is largely derived, not from the artery of the ligament of the head, but from ascending branches of the medial and lateral femoral circumflex arteries . these vessels ascend the neck of the femur deep to its covering of synovial membrane to supply the femoral head. 14 previous next the integrity of the blood supply info to the head of the femur is critical to determine when assessing a femoral fracture . a fracture of the femoral neck can disrupt the blood supply to the head of the femur. this can cause avascular necrosis of the femoral head, and necessitate a hip replacement.

since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: demonstrate and name the three movement pairs of the hip joint. describe how the attachment of muscles to the femur, and their direction of pull, will cause each of these movements. identify all structures indicated on the ap x-ray of the hip region provided. on the os coxa with ligaments prosection, identify the sacrotuberous and sacrospinous ligaments, the greater and lesser sciatic foramina, the inguinal ligament or its location. name the two regions connected by the greater and lesser sciatic foramina, the obturator canal, and the gap deep to the inguinal ligament. on the closed hip joint prosection, identify the joint capsule. what two movements are limited by the intrinsic ligaments of the hip joint? on the open hip joint prosection, identify the acetabular labrum. of what tissue type is it composed? what is its function? identify the transverse acetabular ligament and the ligament of the head of the femur. what is contained within the ligament of the head? distinguish those surfaces within the joint that are covered with articular cartilage from those covered with synovial membrane. describe the blood supply to the head of the femur and its relationship to fractures of the femur. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on. 14.3 progress check 1 15 previous next

when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to recognize and describe the: bony and soft tissue components of the knee joint movements permitted at the knee joint 14.3 the knee joint: objectives 16 previous next 2015 elsevier

14.3 movements of the knee joint the knee is a uniaxial, hinge synovial joint at which flexion and extension take place. the major muscle groups involved are the: hamstrings, in the posterior compartment of the thigh, which pull vertically upward across the back of the joint to flex the knee, and the quadriceps femoris, in the anterior compartment of the thigh, which pull vertically upward across the front of the joint to extend the knee. 17 previous next

14.3 the knee locks in extension 18 next stand on one leg and move your other knee through flexion and tas k extension. feel the contraction of your hamstrings and quadriceps, respectively, as you perform these movements. now, while standing on both feet with your knees in full extension, relax your quadriceps; you do not collapse to the floor in response to gravity because your knees have locked in the extended position. knees lock in full extension with a slight medial rotation of the femur on the tibia. when knee flexion is initiated, the contraction of a small muscle, the popliteus, causes a slight lateral rotation of the femur on the tibia, which unlocks the knee, allowing the hamstrings to flex the joint. the knee involves two articulations. the articulation between the distal femur and proximal tibia is weight-bearing. it includes two fibrocartilagenous menisci interposed between the two bones. the second articulation, that between the distal femur and patella, alters the direction of pull of the quadriceps femoris tendon so as to facilitate its ability to extend the knee.

14.3 the distal femur the distal end of the femur broadens to form its surface for articulation with the tibia and patella. 19 previous next and identify the labelled features at its distal end. instructions follow on the next slide. pick up the bony femur provided tas k

14.3 features of the distal femur tibia. place your thumb into the deep fossa between the condyles, posteriorly, and you have identified the intercondylar fossa. identify the lateral and medial walls of the intercondylar fossa; it is here that the anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments of the knee attach, respectively. 20 previous next identify the medial and lateral condyles, which articulate with the superior surface of the tas k on the posterior aspect of the distal femur, superior to the condyles, notice the triangular area between the diverging ends of the linea aspera. this is the popliteal surface of the femur. follow the condyles to the anterior aspect of the distal femur and notice that they meet as the patellar surface, which, not surprisingly, articulates with the patella. identify the medial and lateral epicondyles, to which the collateral ligaments of the knee attach, and, proximal to the medial epicondyle, the adductor tubercle, to which a powerful adductor muscle of the thigh attaches. the adductor tubercle is a significant landmark in the passage of vessels between the thigh and the leg .

14.3 the patella the patella is the largest sesamoid bone in the body. it forms, postnatally, in response to the friction of the quadriceps femoris tendon rubbing against the distal femur during flexion and extension of the knee. 21 previous next pick up the patella with which youve been provided. notice that it is an inverted triangle; tas k its superior base attaches to the quadriceps tendon and its inferior apex attaches to the patellar ligament. identify, on its posterior surface, its medial and lateral facets. articulate these surfaces with the medial and lateral condyles of the femur, and notice that the ridge between the patellar facets fits nicely into the groove between the femoral condyles, anteriorly.

14.3 the function of the patella the patella protects the tendon of the quadriceps femoris muscle from rubbing against the distal femur. it also increases the angle at which the quadriceps femoris muscle pulls on the tibia; thus, the quadriceps is able to generate a greater torque for the same force. this makes it easer for us to move the tibia, as demonstrated in the video below. 22 previous next

find its proximal end and identify its superior surface, sometimes called the tibial plateau . identify the articular surfaces of the tibial plateau, the medial and lateral facets, which articulate with their respective femoral condyles. a crescent-shaped, fibrocartilagenous meniscus is associated with each facet. between the facets, identify the intercondylar eminence. it is in this region that the medial and lateral menisci attach, as well as the cruciate ligaments. 14.3 the tibial plateau the tibia contributes to the knee joint; the fibula does not. 23 previous next choose a tibia from amongst the bones with which youve been provided. tas k

14.3 femoral tibial articulation 24 previous next surfaces of the femur change as it moves, such that the flatter regions of the femoral condyles articulate with the tibial facets in extension, and the rounder regions articulate in flexion. this relationship contributes to the stability of the extended knee. medial and lateral facets of the tibia, and move the femur through flexion and extension. observe how the articulating articulate the femoral condyles with the tas k

the strong collateral ligaments that stabilize the medial and lateral aspects of the knee joint. identify the tibial tuberosity, the traction epiphysis formed by the attachment of the patellar ligament, which transfers the pull of the quadriceps femoris to the anterior aspect of the proximal tibia. 14.3 the proximal tibia 25 previous next identify the medial and lateral condyles of the tibia. these traction epiphyses are formed by tas k

it does not participate to the knee joint, nor does it bear weight. identify the head and neck of the fibula and articulate the facet on its head with the facet on the posterolateral aspect of the proximal tibia, inferior to the lateral condyle. realize that the head of the fibula is a point 14.3 the proximal fibula 26 previous next pick up the fibula, with which youve been provided. the fibula is the lateral bone of the leg. tas k of attachment for both the lateral collateral ligament of the knee and a hamstring muscle, the biceps femoris. identify the neck of the fibula; the common fibular (peroneal) nerve, a major nerve of the leg, is closely associated with its lateral aspect, where it can become compressed .
14.3 test yourself! ap knee x-ray 27 previous next show answers radiopaedia.org, rid: 36689
14.3 test yourself! lateral knee x-ray 28 previous next show answers journal of education & teaching of emergency medicine, 2016

14.3 the knee joint 29 previous next the articular capsule that encloses the knee joint has been removed in this specimen, allowing you to study its interior. the knee joint is stabilized by a variety of soft-tissue structures, including ligaments and menisci. the prosected knee joint and knee model, with which you have been provided, demonstrate these structures. use both of these resources, as appropriate, for the following exercise. unwrap the prosected knee joints. tas k feel the articular surfaces, the femoral condyles, the tibial facets and the patellar facets. notice that they are smooth and slick. articular (hyaline) cartilage covers these surfaces.

14.3 menisci 30 previous next gently move the knee through flexion and extension and observe that the surfaces of the femoral condyles that contact the tibial facets in extension are flat, while those which contacts the tibial facets in flexion are more curved. identify the medial and lateral menisci. tas k the menisci are crescent-shaped, fibrocartilagenous articular discs that function to improve the congruity between the femoral condyles and the tibial facets. the two ends of each crescent are attached in the intercondylar region of the tibial plateau, and the two menisci are attached together anteriorly by the transverse ligament . the shape and pliability of the menisci accommodates the changing articular surfaces with movement, and improves the stability of the joint. the medial meniscus is more fixed in position, while the lateral meniscus is more mobile. this is because, unlike the lateral meniscus, the medial meniscus is attached around its periphery to the internal surface of the joint capsule. its relative immobility renders the medial meniscus more prone to tears than the lateral meniscus.

14.3 the fibrous joint capsule while the fibrous joint capsule has been removed to create the prosection that you are studying and is not demonstrated in the model, it is important to appreciate its extent and its areas of reinforcement. the fibrous joint capsule completely encloses the knee joint. anteriorly, it is attached to the margins of the patella and the patellar ligament, and is reinforced superolaterally by collagenous extensions of the quadriceps tendon. medially, it is reinforced by the medial (tibial) collateral ligament (mcl), which is an intrinsic ligament of the joint capsule . 31 previous next this is in contrast to the lateral aspect of the joint capsule: the lateral (fibular) collateral ligament (lcl) is an extrinsic ligament of the knee, unattached to the external surface of the joint capsule. the popliteus muscle passes obliquely across the posterior aspect of the knee, through the fibrous joint capsule, to attach to the lateral epicondyle of the femur. with contraction, it laterally rotates the femur to unlock the extended knee, and permit flexion to occur.

14.3 collateral ligaments all hinge joints have collateral ligaments which maintain the alignment of the articulating surfaces through flexion and extension. on the prosected knee and the knee model, 32 previous next ligament: it is a thick cord that crosses and reinforces the lateral aspect of the knee. notice the shape of the medial collateral ligament: it is a broad, flat band that crosses and reinforces the medial aspect of the knee. identify the medial and lateral collateral ligaments. notice the shape of the lateral collateral tas k flexion and extension and observe that the collateral ligaments are move the knee through tas k remember, if the capsule of the joint were intact, you would observe that the lateral collateral ligament is an extrinsic ligament, separate from the joint capsule, while the medial collateral ligament is an intrinsic ligament, and is, in reality, simply a thickening of the joint capsule. taut in extension and relatively loose in flexion. these ligaments limit extension and stabilize the extended knee.

14.3 cruciate ligaments the femur and tibia are also joined by the cruciate ligaments which occupy the intercondylar fossa of the femur. each is named according to the position of its attachment on the tibial plateau, as illustrated in the accompanying figure. 33 previous next extending from the anterior aspect of the intercondylar area of the tibial plateau, to the lateral wall of the intercondylar fossa of the femur (i.e. the lateral condyle), posteriorly. identify the anterior cruciate ligament, acl, tas k the acl and pcl stabilize the relative positions of the femur and tibia, particularly in the sagittal plane. identify the posterior cruciate ligament, pcl, extending from the posterior limit of the intercondylar area of the tibial plateau to the medial wall of the intercondylar fossa of the femur (i.e. the medial condyle), anteriorly.

14.3 anterior and posterior drawer test 34 previous next the tibia anteriorly. note (even from the figure) how this movement is limited by the acl. if the acl were torn, the tibia would move anteriorly relative to the femur. this is the anterior drawer sign, and indicates a torn acl. holding the femur stationary, gently try to move tas k the tibia posteriorly. note (even from the figure) how this movement is limited by the pcl. if the pcl were torn, the tibia would move posteriorly relative to the femur. this is the posterior drawer sign. holding the femur stationary, gently try to move tas k the examiner attempting to move the tibia anteriorly and posteriorly relative to a fixed femur (i.e., with the patient seated), as you just did with the prosection. if the cruciate ligaments are intact, the tibia cannot be displaced. in the clinic, the cruciate ligaments are assessed by i n fo if the pcl is torn, the examiner will be able to displace the tibia posteriorly relative to the femur - the posterior drawer sign. if the acl is torn, the examiner will be able to displace the tibia anteriorly relative to the femur - the anterior drawer sign.

14.3 the synovial membrane of the knee joint 35 previous next in the knee, synovial membrane extends from the margins of the articular cartilages to the margins of the menisci. anteriorly, the infrapatellar fat pad intervenes between the patellar ligament and the synovial membrane. its malleability accommodates changes in the shape of the joint space with movement. posteriorly, synovial membrane reflects off the fibrous joint capsule to surround the cruciate ligaments. this excludes these ligaments from the fluid-filled joint space, but positions them within the fibrous joint capsule. synovial membrane lines all non-articular surfaces within a joint space. it may directly line the internal surface of the fibrous joint capsule, or there may be tissue sandwiched in between the synovial membrane and the fibrous joint capsule. this tissue may be adipose (the infrapatellar fat pad), a tendon (that of the popliteus muscle) or a ligament (the cruciate ligaments). in this latter case, the intervening tissue is therefore intracapsular, but it is excluded from the fluid-filled joint space by the synovial membrane.

14.3 bursae of the knee 36 previous next bursae allow structures associated with a joint to move relative to each other in a friction-free manner. they are composed of synovial membrane, and contain a capillary layer of synovial fluid. bursae may be subcutaneous, in which case they allow skin to move freely, or subtendinous, in which case, they allow tendons to move freely. bursae may be synovial membrane-lined extensions of the joint cavity. in the knee, the subpopliteal recess is a bursae between the lateral meniscus and the tendon of the popliteus muscle, which allows them to move freely relative to each other . the suprapatellar bursa is an extension of the joint space superiorly, between the tendon of the quadriceps and the distal femur, which allows this tendon to move freely over the bone. bursae may also be sacs of synovial fluid isolated from the joint cavity. in the knee, this is the case of the prepatellar bursa and the subcutaneous and deep infrapatellar bursae. bursitis info bursitis is the inflammation of a bursa .

identify the anterior and posterior surfaces of the patella, its apex and base, and its medial and lateral facets. what is the function of the patella wrt movement of the knee joint? on the tibia, identify the tibial plateau, the tibial facets, the intercondylar eminence. identify the medial and lateral condyles, and tibial tuberosity. what structures attach at each? identify the head and neck of the fibula. what ligament attaches to the head of the fibula? what nerve lies adjacent to the neck of the fibula? identify all structures indicated on the ap and lateral x-rays of the knee provided. on the opened knee prosection, identify the medial and lateral menisci. what is their function? which is more fixed in position? what is the significance of this? identify the medial and lateral collateral ligaments. which is intrinsic, and which is extrinsic? identify the medial and lateral cruciate ligaments. how are they named? to which wall of the intercondylar fossa does each attach? explain the theory behind the anterior and posterior drawer signs, and what each indicates. what is a subcutaneous bursa vs a subtendinous bursa? 14.1 ligaments associated with the os coxa i identify the sacrotuberous and sacrospinous ligaments. identify the greater and lesser sciatic foramina. identify the inguinal ligament, if it is present, or represent it using the piece of string provided. notice the gap between the inguinal ligament and the hip bone. muscles, nerves, blood vessels and lymphatics pass between the abdomen and the thigh through this gap. 7 previous next unwrap the specimen labelled os coxa with ligaments. tas k

14.1 ligaments associated with the os coxa ii the obturator canal, which joins the pelvis and medial thigh the gap between the inguinal ligament and the pelvic bone, which joins the pelvis and anterior thigh the greater sciatic foramen, which joins the pelvis with the gluteal region the lesser sciatic foramen, which joins the gluteal region with the perineum. 8 previous next now, pass a probe through tas k moisten and rewrap this specimen, and put it back in its bag. the various passages between the pelvis and lower limb, through which muscles, vessels and nerves pass between the pelvis and the thigh:

14.1 the joint capsule and intrinsic ligaments i identify the articular capsule (a), a dense irregular ct capsule that encloses the joint. note that it extends from the margin of the acetabulum to enclose the femoral head and much of the femoral neck. in certain regions, the collagen fibres of the joint capsule become more regular and the capsule thicker. these are the intrinsic ligaments of the joint capsule. you are not responsible for identifying the individual ligaments. 9 previous next a. the capsule of the hip joint extends to the intertrochanteric line, anteriorly. b, c. the intrinsic ligaments of the capsule spiral from posterior to anterior. unwrap the specimen of the closed hip joint. tas k

14.1 the joint capsule and intrinsic ligaments ii gently, move the femur through flexion and extension. notice that with flexion, the ligaments become loose, but with extension, they become tight. move the femur through abduction and adduction. notice that with adduction, the capsule becomes loose, but with abduction it becomes tight. therefore, extension and abduction are limited by the joint capsule and its intrinsic ligaments. moisten and rewrap the specimen. 10 previous next notice that the fibres of these ligaments spiral anteriorly around the anatomical neck of the femur to their points of attachment tas k a. the capsule of the hip joint extends to the intertrochanteric line, anteriorly. b, c. the intrinsic ligaments of the capsule spiral from posterior to anterior.

14.1 internal features of the hip joint 11 previous next identify the acetabular labrum, tas k notice that it deepens the socket for articulation with the femoral head, thus increasing the congruity between the articulating elements and stabilizing the joint. touch the femoral head and tas k a fibrocartilagenous ring that surrounds the acetabular margin the lunate surface of the acetabulum, the articulating surfaces of the hip joint. notice how smooth and slippery they are. what tissue covers these surfaces? identify the transverse acetabular ligament, which spans the acetabular notch and creates tas k the acetabular foramen. identify the ligament of the head of the femur, which extends from the acetabular foramen to the fovea of the femur. it contains the artery of the ligament of the head, a branch of the obturator artery, that supplied blood to the head of the developing femur. unwrap the specimen labelled open hip joint.

14.1 synovial membrane of the hip joint which lines the internal surface of the joint capsule, as well as the anatomical neck of the femur. deep to the synovial membrane on the anatomical neck, blood vessels ascend to the head of the femur. 12 previous next synovial membrane covers all non-articular surfaces within a synovial joint; this includes the internal surface of the fibrous joint capsule. the capsule of the hip joint is loose, which is one of the reasons why the hip joint is so mobile. therefore, synovial membrane extends from the periphery of the head of the femur, down its neck, and then reflects off the neck of the femur to cover the internal surface of the joint capsule as far as to the margin of the acetabulum. identify the synovial membrane, tas k

14.1 blood supply to the hip joint in most adults, the blood supply to the head of the femur is largely derived, not from the artery of the ligament of the head, but from ascending branches of the medial and lateral femoral circumflex arteries . these vessels ascend between the neck of the femur and its coating of synovial membrane to supply the femoral head. 13 previous next the integrity of the blood supply info to the head of the femur is critical to determine when assessing a femoral fracture.

when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to name and describe the actions of the major muscles acting on the pectoral girdle, glenohumeral and elbow joints. 14.2 objectives 2 previous next

the upper limb articulates with the axial skeleton only at the sternoclavicular joint. it is otherwise primarily attached to the body by muscles, which contributes to its great mobility. the pectoral girdle (clavicle and scapula) carries the arm, forearm and hand. movement of the pectoral girdle, therefore, relative to the thorax, contributes to the overall position of the arm and hand. muscles extending from the axial skeleton to the pectoral girdle control its position relative to the thorax and will be studied first. the glenohumeral joint is the most mobile in the body. muscles that extend to the humerus, either from the axial skeleton or the pectoral girdle, cross the glenohumeral joint and therefore act on it; these will be studied next. the elbow joint permits flexion and extension. the proximal radioulnar joint contributes to pronation and supination of the forearm. muscles that extend from the pectoral girdle or humerus to the forearm cross the elbow joint and therefore act on it. these will be studied last. a point of nomenclature: the words origin and insertion are often used to describe the two attachment points of a muscle. in general, the origin is more proximal and the insertion is more distal. when a muscle contracts, the two attachment points are pulled closer together and movement occurs at the intervening joint. previous next 14.2 introduction 3

14.2 elevation and depression of the scapula to their starting position. this is elevation and depression of the scapula relative to the thorax. 4 previous next shrug your shoulders and then return them tas k muscles that attach to the scapula from above, pull upward on the scapula when they contract (green arrow), causing elevation. muscles that attach to the scapula from below, pull downward on the scapula when they contract (red arrow), causing depression. noting the position of a muscle relative to a joint or bone (in this case, superior or inferior to the scapula) and its direction of pull (in this case, vertically) is the key to understanding the action of muscles, rather than memorizing the action of muscles. facts that are understood are retained; facts that are memorized are lost. this is my approach to teaching msk anatomy. it should be your approach to learning it. from the anatomical position,

14.2 the trapezius elevates, depresses and retracts the scapula 7 previous next on the side dissected to show superficial muscles, identify the trapezius muscle. run your finger along the entire length of its origin from the occipital bone of the skull and extending throughout the length of the turn your attention to the prosection at the centre table labelled, superficial and deep back. tas k cervical and thoracic regions of the vertebral column. because its origin is so extensive, the trapezius is capable of many actions, depending on which subset of the muscle is activated. notice that the upper fibres descend to insert onto the lateral clavicle and spine of the scapula. run your finger along this insertion. these fibres, acting in isolation, contract to elevate the pectoral girdle (green arrow), as when you shrug your shoulders. notice that the middle fibres extend horizontally from the lower cervical and upper thoracic regions to the spine of the scapula. these fibres, acting in isolation, contract to pull the scapula toward the vertebral column (blue arrow), and therefore retract the scapula. notice that the lower fibres ascend to insert onto the medial end of the spine of the scapula these fibres, acting in isolation, contract to depress the scapula (red arrow). because of its broad proximal attachment, the trapezius is capable of any one of these actions, depending on the subset of muscle fibres activated. play animation

14.2 the trapezius contributes to abduction of the ul 8 previous next you can also activate both the upper and lower fibres of the trapezius synchronously. as illustrated using our teeter-totter, working together, the upper fibres pull the lateral angle of the scapula upward (green arrow) while the lower fibres pull the medial border of the scapula downward (red arrow). therefore, the trapezius is also capable of contributing to abduction of the upper limb. again, the action of the trapezius at any given time is determined by the subset of its fibres activated. replay animation

14.2 muscles and movements of the glenohumeral joint 12 previous next position, remind yourself of the movement pairs that take place at the glenohumeral joint. starting in the anatomical tas k in abduction and adduction, the humerus moves away from, and then toward, the midline, respectively. the movement takes place in the coronal plane. both of these movement pairs involve a change in the angle of the humerus relative to the long axis of the body. in lateral and medial rotation, the humerus remains parallel to the long axis of the body while it rotates around its long axis, away from, and then toward the body, respectively. in studying the muscles that act on the glenohumeral joint, well rely on the direction of pull of the muscles to inform us of their action(s). in flexion and extension, the humerus moves anteriorly and posteriorly, respectively. the movement takes place in the sagittal plane.

14.2 the rotator cuff muscles 18 previous next the rotator cuff is a group of four muscles that extend from the scapula to the proximal humerus. acting together, they stabilize the glenohumeral joint; their tonic contraction pulls the head of the humerus into the glenoid fossa, and they thereby, as a group, help to maintain the alignment and integrity of the joint. the rotator cuff muscles are the subscapularis, supraspinatus, infraspinatus and teres minor.

14.2 the deltoid the deltoid gets it name from its triangular shape, like the greek letter delta (), although, in the case of the deltoid, the base of the triangle is superior and its apex is inferior. 22 previous next along the u-shaped origin of the deltoid: the lateral clavicle, the acromion process, and the spine of the scapula. notice that the origin of the deltoid is also the insertion of the trapezius. the unwrap the prosection labelled full arm. run your finger tas k origin of the deltoid forms the base of the inverted triangle. follow the fibres of the deltoid over the superolateral surface of the glenohumeral joint to its point of insertion at the deltoid tuberosity of the humerus. when the fibres of the deltoid muscle contract they cause abduction of the glenohumeral joint (green arrow), but only if this movement is first initiated by the supraspinatus, as already noted. the anterior fibres of the deltoid cross vertically anterior to the glenohumeral joint, and can therefore contribute to flexion of this joint (blue arrow). the posterior fibres of the deltoid cross vertically posterior to the glenohumeral joint, and can therefore contribute to extension of this joint (red arrow).

14.2 muscular action at the elbow joint 23 previous next as illustrated (a), the elbow permits flexion and extension. it should make sense to you that muscles that pass vertically, anterior to the elbow joint cause flexion, while muscles that pass vertically posterior to the elbow joint cause extension. recall from unit 3 that the arm is divided by fascial septae into an anterior (flexor) and a posterior (extensor) compartment. pronation and supination (b) occur in the forearm at the proximal and distal radioulnar joints. these actions occur with medial and lateral rotation of the radius, respectively. for a muscle to carry out either of these actions, it must exert a pull perpendicular to the long axis of the radius.

14.1 the shoulder joint: objectives previous next when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to recognize and describe the: bony and soft tissue components of the glenohumeral, acromioclavicular and sternoclavicular joints movements permitted at these joints 2

14.1 overview of the upper limb the upper limb can be subdivided into regions as illustrated in the accompanying figure: the shoulder, arm, forearm and hand. the only articulation between the upper limb and the axial skeleton is the sternoclavicular joint. otherwise, the upper limb is attached to the axial skeleton by muscles. this contributes to its great mobility, but also to its relative instability. the primary function of the upper limb is to position the hand in space so as to allow us to carry out our intended tasks. previous next 3

scapula: its anterior surface, composed largely of the subscapular fossa; its posterior surface, subdivided by the scapular spine into the supraspinous and infraspinous fossae; medial, lateral and superior borders; superior, inferior and lateral angles; the glenoid cavity, the acromion process and coracoid process. see figure here: proximal humerus: its head, greater tubercle, lesser tubercle and intertubercular groove; its anatomical neck and surgical neck. see figure here: 14.1 the skeleton of the shoulder region 4 previous next the skeleton of the shoulder region consists of the pectoral girdle (clavicle and scapula) and the proximal humerus. in unit 3, you studied the skeleton of the upper limb. review the following features of the disarticulated bones before proceeding. tas k clavicle: sternal (medial) and acromial (lateral) ends, superior and inferior surfaces, the medial portion, convex anteriorly and the lateral portion, concave anteriorly. clavicle

14.1 articulations of the shoulder region 5 previous next identify the sternoclavicular joint, the only articulation between the upper limb and the axial skeleton, where the medial end of the clavicle articulates with the manubrium of the sternum. identify the clavicle, scapula and humerus. tas k identify the acromioclavicular joint, where the lateral end of the clavicle articulates with the acromion process of the scapula. this unites the clavicle and scapula, forming the pectoral girdle. because the acromioclavicular joint permits little movement, the pectoral girdle largely moves as a unit. finally, identify the glenohumeral joint, between the glenoid fossa of the scapula and the head of the humerus; it connects the pectoral girdle to the arm. on the hanging skeleton,

14.1 the acromioclavicular joint the bones of the pectoral girdle, the clavicle and scapula, are joined at the acromioclavicular joint. it permits little movement, so these two bones largely move as a unit relative to the thorax. movement of the pectoral girdle relative to the thorax translates into movement of the arm, and therefore the forearm and hand. the movement of the scapula is a major factor contributing to the position of the hand in space, as you will learn. 7 previous next it is reinforced by an intrinsic ligament, the acromioclavicular ligament. identify the coracoclavicular ligament, extending between the coracoid process and the lateral end of the clavicle . this extrinsic ligament of the acromioclavicular joint bears much of the weight of the arm and maintains the alignment of the clavicle and acromion. unwrap the specimen labelled closed shoulder joint. identify the acromioclavicular joint. tas k

14.1 the sternoclavicular joint the sternoclavicular joint is described variably as a plane joint, a biaxial joint and a triaxial joint. in any case, it is a stable joint, reinforced by intrinsic and extrinsic ligaments. the costoclavicular ligament is an extrinsic ligament of this joint that binds down the clavicle to the first rib, thus limiting movement at its medial end. a fibrocartilagenous articular disc completely separates the joint space into two compartments. as the bones of the pectoral girdle uniteat the acromioclavicular joint, they move as a unit. hence, the movement of the clavicle translates into movement of the scapula, and vice versa. 8 previous next now, move your scapulae forward and backward in the horizontal plane; angular movement at the sternoclavicular joint results in protraction and retraction of the shoulders. the arm, attached to the pectoral girdle at the glenohumeral joint, is carried along with movements of the pectoral girdle; movement of the pectoral girdle is a large component of the mobility of the upper limb as a whole. i dont know.. this angular movement at the sternoclavicular joint in the coronal plane is properly called elevation and depression. shrug your shoulders, as if to say, tas k

14.1 the glenohumeral joint 9 previous next it permits three movement pairs: flexion / extension abduction / adduction medial / lateral rotation the glenohumeral joint is the most mobile joint in the body; this comes at the price of instability. the glenohumeral joint is a triaxial, ball and socket joint between the head of the humerus and the glenoid cavity of the scapula. ensure that every member is crystal clear on what each of these movements are. this knowledge is critical to your ability to understand the relationship between the orientation of a carry out these movements with your lab group. tas k muscle relative to the joint and its action at the joint. by understanding this relationship, the action of the muscle is easily understood, making memorization unnecessary.

14.1 glenohumeral joint: articulating surfaces 10 previous next notice the disparity between the size of the articular surfaces involved: the glenoid fossa is very small relative to the head of the humerus. look at the glenohumeral joint of the hanging skeleton. tas k this is the basis of the great mobility of the glenohumeral joint. move the glenohumeral joint of the skeleton through the full range of abduction / adduction, flexion / extension, and medial / lateral rotation, and observe how the region of the humeral head in contact with the glenoid fossa changes. clearly, the alignment of the articulating surfaces is not maintained by the congruous nature of the bony articulating surfaces, as you will see is the case with the elbow joint! in the glenohumeral joint, soft tissue, such as muscles, tendons and ligaments, maintains the alignment of the articulating surfaces; this make the glenohumeral joint the most commonly dislocated joint in the body.

14.1 the coracoacromial arch 11 previous next the closed shoulder joint, and identify the coracoacromial ligament. turn your attention to tas k this tough ligament joins the coracoid and acromion processes of the scapula, and together with them, forms the coracoacromial arch. notice that these structures reinforce the superior aspect of the glenohumeral joint, and resist superior dislocation of the joint.

anatomical neck of the humerus. in the anatomical position, the joint capsule is redundant ; this redundancy accommodates abduction of the shoulder. the joint capsule is reinforced anteriorly and superiorly by intrinsic ligaments , which resist dislocation of the joint in these directions. 14.1 the fibrous joint capsule 12 previous next joint, notice the extent of the fibrous joint capsule: it extends from the margins of the glenoid fossa to the base of the again, looking at the closed shoulder tas k of the biceps brachii emerging from the joint capsule and lying in the intertubercular groove, whereby it gains access to the identify the tendon of the long head tas k anterior compartment of the arm. identify the transverse humeral ligament , which holds the tendon of the long head of the biceps in place .

14.1 glenohumeral joint: intracapsular structures 13 previous next feel the articular surfaces of the glenohumeral joint, the glenoid fossa and the head of the humerus. you will find them to be smooth and slippery, because they are lined with articular (hyaline) cartilage. unwrap specimen: open shoulder joint. tas k identify, encircling the glenoid fossa, the glenoid labrum, a fibrocartilagenous ring that expands and deepens the glenoid fossa, increasing joint stability. identify the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii arising superior to the glenoid fossa, and coursing, within the fibrous joint capsule, over the superior aspect of the glenohumeral joint; it helps resist superior dislocation of the joint.

14.1 synovial membrane synovial membrane lines all non-articular surfaces within a joint space. it lines the internal surface of the fibrous joint capsule, but realize that there may be structures sandwiched in between the synovial membrane and the fibrous joint capsule. in this latter case, the intervening structure is therefore intracapsular, but it is excluded from the fluid-filled joint space by synovial membrane. one such example in the glenohumeral joint is the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii, already described; it runs deep to the fibrous joint capsule, surrounded by a sleeve of the synovial membrane that lines its internal surface. 14 previous next margin of the glenoid fossa, along the internal surface of the fibrous joint capsule, to the base of the anatomical neck of the humerus. trace the synovial membrane from the tas k

14.1 blood supply to the glenohumeral joint 15 previous next the blood supply to the glenohumeral joint, including the head of the humerus, is largely derived from ascending branches of the anterior and posterior humeral circumflex arteries . the anatomical neck is a common site info of humeral fracture. it is not uncommon for such a fracture to be complicated by disruption of the blood supply to the humeral head, which may result in avascular necrosis.

14.1 bursae of the shoulder region 16 previous next recall that bursae are sacs of synovial membrane which contain a capillary layer of synovial fluid. bursae intervene between a two structures that normally move relative to each other (muscle or tendon and bone, muscle or tendon and fibrous joint capsule, skin and bone). bursae thereby eliminate friction between such structures, preventing tissue damage and inflammation. a number of bursae intervene between the fibrous joint capsule of the glenohumeral joint and overlying structures. the subtendinous bursa of subscapularis intervenes between the subscapularis muscle (a rotator cuff muscle) and the underlying fibrous joint capsule. these are the largest of the bursae of the shoulder region. bursae will have been removed during the preparation of the prosected specimens. the subacromial bursa intervenes between the acromion process and the fibrous joint capsule. the subdeltoid bursa intervenes between the deltoid muscle and the fibrous joint capsule. in some people these two bursae are continuous with each other, as illustrated.

on the closed shoulder joint, identify the acromioclavicular joint and ligament. identify the coracoclavicular ligament. what are the two parts of the coracoclavicular ligament? demonstrate and name the three movement pairs that take place at the glenohumeral joint. how do the articulating surfaces of the gh joint contribute to its great mobility? on the closed shoulder joint, identify the coracoacromial ligament. what three structures comprise the coracoacromial arch? the arch resists dislocation of the gh joint in what direction? what is the importance of the redundancy of the gh joint capsule? intrinsic ligaments of the gh joint resist its dislocation in what directions? identify the tendon of the biceps brachii and transverse humeral ligament. on the open shoulder joint, identify which surfaces are covered in hyaline cartilage, and which are covered in synovial membrane. identify the glenoid labrum. what is its function? identify the tendon of the biceps brachii. how can a tendon or collection of adipose tissue be intracapsular but excluded from the joint space? what vessels give rise to the blood supply to the gh joint? what is a bursa and what is its function? name and indicate the location of three bursae associated with the gh joint. in each case, name the two structures the bursa intervenes between. which joint in the shoulder region includes a fibrocartilagenous articular disc that completely subdivides the joint space? 14.1 the skeleton of the elbow joint within the capsule of the elbow joint are three articulations. 19 previous next youve been provided. you learned the skeleton of the upper limb in unit 3. be sure you can identify the following features of the disarticulated bones before proceeding with new material. choose a humerus, ulna and radius from among the disarticulated bones with which tas k distal humerus, anterior aspect: humeral condyle, consisting of the capitulum and trochlea, the radial and coronoid fossae, the medial and lateral epicondyles, the medial and lateral supraepicondylar ridges. distal humerus, posterior aspect: trochlea, olecranon fossa. proximal ulna: the olecranon and coronoid processes, the trochlear notch, the ulnar tuberosity, the radial notch. see figure here: proximal radius: its head, neck, the radial tuberosity. see figure here: distal humerus

14.1 articulations of the elbow joint the elbow is a compound joint, which means it involves more than one articulation. 22 previous next upper limb provided, identify the two articulations that comprise the elbow joint: using either the articulated skeleton or the articulated tas k i) humeroulnar joint: the trochlea of the humerus with the trochlear notch of the ulna, and ii) humeroradial joint: the capitulum of the humerus with the head of the radius. the elbow joint is a hinge joint that permits flexion and extension. move the bony elbow through flexion and extension. note the following: i) in flexion, the head of the radius occupies the radial fossa of the humerus and the coronoid process of the ulna occupies the coronoid fossa of the humerus; ii) in extension, the olecranon process of the ulna occupies the olecranon fossa of the humerus

14.1 the proximal radioulnar joint 23 previous next within the capsule of the elbow joint is a third articulation, the proximal radioulnar joint. proximal radioulnar joint: the head of the radius and the radial notch of the ulna. the proximal radioulnar joint is a pivot joint that rotates medially and laterally. identify the articulating surfaces of the tas k it, along with the distal radioulnar joint, permit pronation and supination to occur. with the elbow extended, move the articulated bony forearm through pronation and supination. with the elbow flexed, move the forearm through pronation and supination. notice that pronation and supination are independent of the position of the elbow.

14.1 the fibrous joint capsule and ligaments 24 previous next notice the extent of the fibrous joint capsule. proximally, it encloses the olecranon fossa posteriorly, and the radial and coronoid fossae anteriorly. distally, it extends to enclose the radial head and to attach to the olecranon and coronoid processes unwrap the prosected elbow with the fibrous joint capsule intact. tas k of the elbow, intrinsic ligaments that reinforce the joint capsule and help maintain the alignment of the articulating surfaces. identify the medial (ulnar) and lateral (radial) collateral ligaments tas k identify the annular ligament, a third intrinsic ligament of the joint capsule that encloses the radial head, holding it in position against the radial notch of the ulna. it stabilizes the proximal radioulnar joint, holding the radial head in the radial notch of the ulna and against the capitulum as it pivots in pronation and supination of the forearm. radial head subluxation, or nursemaid elbow, is a common injury info of preschool-aged children, in whom the annular ligament is not fully formed. it occurs when the radial head is pulled out of the annular ligament, and therefore out of alignment with the radial notch of the ulna and capitulum. gently flex the joint and notice that the fibrous joint capsule becomes loose anteriorly. gently extend the joint and notice that the fibrous joint capsule becomes loose posteriorly.

14.1 synovial membrane realize that the internal surface of the fibrous joint capsule is lined by synovial membrane. fat pads intervene between the synovial membrane and the fibrous joint capsule anteriorly and posteriorly to accommodate the changes in the shape of the joint cavity that occur with movement. the synovial membrane extends between the head of the radius and the annular ligament; thus all three of these articulations are enclosed within one joint space. 25 previous next

14.1 the interior of the elbow joint 26 previous next again, identify the medial and lateral collateral ligaments, and the annular ligament. feel the articulating surfaces, and notice that they are smooth and slippery. what tissue covers these surfaces? unwrap the prosected elbow with the opened joint capsule. tas k anatomy umft 2002
