14.4 muscles acting on the back, hip & knee back to station selection resources articulated skeleton articulated bony lower limb prosection of superficial and deep back muscles (at the shared table) prosected specimen demonstrating the muscles of the gluteal region prosected lower limb demonstrating the muscles of the thigh next

when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to describe the major muscles acting on the back, hip and knee, including their actions. 14.4 objectives 2 previous next

14.4 introduction: the back the skeletal framework of the back consists largely of the vertebral column, but because the musculature of the back extends to the base of the skull, the proximal ribs and the ilium, these structures are considered skeletal components of the back, as well. extrinsic muscles of the back, by definition, have one point of attachment to a skeletal component of the back, and another point of attachment to a skeletal component of the upper limb. therefore, these muscles act not on the back, but move the upper limb relative to the back. extrinsic muscles of the back are described in exercise 14.4, and include the trapezius and the latissimus dorsi. 3 previous next g2.003 intrinsic muscles of the back, by definition, are wholly in the back; i.e. they connect two skeletal components of the back to each other. they extend from the sacrum and ilium, inferiorly, to the occipital bone, superiorly, with numerous attachments in between to elements of the vertebral column and ribs. therefore, the intrinsic back muscles act to maintain our posture, and to move the back through flexion, extension, rotation and lateral bending. perform these movements yourself and be able to identify them when performed by others.

14.4 intrinsic muscles of the back muscles of the back are organized in layers. the intrinsic muscles of the back are deep to the extrinsic muscles of the back, and are separated from them by a thick fascial sheet, the thoracolumbar fascia. the thoracolumbar fascia i) surrounds and encloses the intrinsic back muscles, ii) it anchors them to their bony framework, and iii) it acts as a point of origin of the extrinsic back muscles and the abdominal muscles. deep to the thoracolumbar fascia are the erector spinae muscles, a major group of intrinsic back muscles. 4 previous next

14.4 identify the erector spinae at the centre table is a prosection demonstrating back muscles. one side is a superficial dissection demonstrating the extrinsic muscles of the back, including the trapezius and the latissimus dorsi. the other side is a deeper dissection demonstrating the intrinsic muscles of the back. go to the centre table and uncover the prosection of the back. on the deep side, 5 previous next paired group of muscles that run parallel to the vertebral column. the erector spinae fill in the gutter between the spinous processes of the vertebral column, medially, and the angles of the ribs, laterally. identify the erector spinae. notice that these are a large, tas k identify the inferior extent of the muscle; it arises from a thick tendon of attachment to the sacrum and ilium, as well as the lumbar and lower thoracic vertebrae. notice that on each side, it is composed of three subdivisions, arranged from medial to lateral . identify its most superior extent, where it attaches to the skull.

14.4 actions of the erector spinae 6 previous next work out the action of the erector spinae when it contracts bilaterally: since these muscles run parallel and posterior to the vertebral column, logically, they extend the back and neck. continuing with the prosection of the back (centre table) tas k work out the action of the erector spinae when it contracts unilaterally: as one side contracts alone, it bends the vertebral column to the ipsilateral side. identify the splenius capitis, extending from the lower cervical and upper thoracic vertebrae to the base of the skull. like the erector spinae, with bilateral contraction it extends the neck. however, with unilateral contraction it rotates the head to ipsilateral side. moisten the specimen and cover it with a damp cloth . go back to station 3.

14.4 rotators of the spine deep to the erector spinae is a second group of intrinsic back muscles, the transversospinalis. as their name suggests, they run from the transverse process of one vertebra to the spinous process of another, filling in the gutter between these vertebral processes bilaterally, along the length of the vertebral column. because of their attachments, when they contract unilaterally, they pull the spinous processes out of line, thereby rotating the vertebral column. when they contract bilaterally, however, they are able to exert equal pull on the spinous processes on both sides and therefore extend the vertebral column. while they are not demonstrated in the prosection, they are beautifully presented in specimens in grants museum, which you are to look at. like the erector spinae, the transversospinalis are subdivided into three groups, but in this case they are arranged from superficial to deep. the superficial fibres are the longest, spanning up to six vertebrae, and the deepest fibres are the shortest, spanning as few as one or two vertebrae. 7 previous next

14.4 innervation of the intrinsic back muscles the intrinsic back muscles are innervated in a segmental fashion by the dorsal rami of the spinal nerves, from cervical levels to sacral levels. dorsal rami also innervate the skin overlying the intrinsic back muscles. 8 previous next ventral rami are responsible for innervating muscle and skin of the anterolateral body wall and the limbs.

14.4 regions of the lower limb the lower limb is divided into regions: the anterior thigh, from the inguinal ligament to the knee joint the gluteal region, posteriorly, from the iliac crest to the gluteal fold the posterior thigh from the gluteal fold to the knee joint, the leg, from the knee joint to the talocrural joint, the foot, distal to the talocrural joint 9 previous next

14.4 sacroiliac joints the pelvic girdle, consisting of the paired ossa coxae, is the part of the lower limb that attaches to the axial skeleton. the pelvic girdle articulates with the axial skeleton at the sacroiliac joint, which is reinforced by numerous robust ligaments. 10 previous next because body weight is transferred to the lower limb through the sacroiliac joints, they are extremely stable articulations, which, as always, comes at the expense of mobility. the sacroiliac joints are synovial joints between the auricular surfaces of the sacrum and ilium. the auricular surfaces are uneven and mesh together to limit movement. they are reinforced by dense ligaments. with age, the sacroiliac joints become fibrous, and can, in some individuals, become ossified.

14.4 the gluteal region i muscles of the gluteal region act on the hip. their specific action depends on their direction of pull across the joint. if you invest a moment to work out the following with your group, you will be rewarded by ultimately understanding (i.e. learning) the actions of these muscles, rather than memorizing them. 11 previous next as illustrated, muscles that pull up on the lateral aspect of the greater trochanter (green arrow) abduct the hip. muscles that pull horizontally across the back of the hip joint, perpendicular to the long axis of the femur (red arrow), laterally rotate the hip. some muscles, however, pull obliquely across the posterior aspect of the hip joint (blue arrow). their pull can be deconstructed into two vectors (dotted arrows): one vector runs vertically, posterior to the hip and causes extension; the other runs horizontally, posterior to the hip, and causes lateral rotation .

14.4 the gluteal region ii 12 previous next a point of nomenclature: the words origin and insertion are often used to describe the two attachment points of a muscle. in general, the origin is more proximal and the insertion is more distal. when a muscle contracts, the two attachment points are pulled closer together and movement occurs at the intervening joint. think about the direction of pull of muscles that carry out these actions: they are logical, and so can be remembered, rather than memorized! stand up and perform these actions: abduction, lateral rotation and extension of the hip. tas k

since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: demonstrate and name the three movement pairs of the vertebral column. describe the position of the thoracolumbar fascia wrt the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the back. on the prosection of the back muscles, identify the erector spinae and splenius capitis. demonstrate and describe the actions of each with unilateral and bilateral contraction. describe the actions of the transversospinalis with unilateral and bilateral contraction. describe the innervation of the intrinsic back muscles. demonstrate and name the three movement pairs of the hip joint. describe how the attachment of muscles to the femur, and their direction of pull, will cause each of these movements. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on. 14.4 progress check 1 13 previous next

14.4 the gluteus maximus stand up and extend one hip. now laterally rotate it. feel the full engagement of your gluteus maximus when the hip is both extended and laterally rotated. moisten this specimen and drape it with a cloth; you will return to it later in the exercise. on its posterior aspect, identify the gluteus maximus muscle. note that this powerful muscle extends obliquely across the posterior aspect of the hip (blue arrow) and so with contraction, it extends and laterally rotates the hip. 14 previous next unwrap the lower limb specimen. tas k notice in the diagram that the gluteus maximus inserts into both the proximal femur and into the iliotibial tract, which will be described next.

14.4 the iliotibial band 15 previous next recall from unit 3 the layers superficial to the muscles of the limbs. these are, from superficial to deep, the skin, superficial fascia and deep fascia. in the thigh, the deep fascia is called the fascia lata. if you need reminding, see here: . the fascia lata encloses the muscles of the thigh like a sleeve. it attaches proximally to the iliac crest, the inguinal ligament, the conjoint ramus, the sacrotuberous ligament, and the sacrum. this line separates the lower limb from back and abdomen. the fascia lata is particularly thick along its lateral aspect, where it forms the iliotibial (it) band (or tract). the it band extends from the iliac crest to the proximal tibia, crossing anterior to the axis of rotation of the knee (red dot). in the accompanying figure, follow the iliotibial band superiorly, and identify, extending to it from the asis, the tensor fascia lata. notice that the gluteus maximus inserts into the iliotibial tract from its posterior aspect. both of these muscles, in addition to acting at the hip joint, exert tension on the iliotibial tract that is transferred to the tibia and stabilizes the lateral aspect of the extended knee.

14.4 the gluteus medius and minimus i 16 previous next the prosection labelled, gluteal region. in this prosection, the gluteus maximus is removed or reflected, revealing structures deep to it. identify, extending downward from the gluteal (lateral) surface of the ilium to the greater trochanter, the gluteus medius. a window will have been notched in the gluteus medius so that you can see, deep to it, the gluteus minimus. both of these muscles pull upward on the greater trochanter over the lateral aspect of the hip (green arrow), and as such, these muscles are abductors of the hip joint. go to the centre table and unwrap tas k

14.4 the gluteus medius and minimus ii 17 previous next floor. notice that your pelvis remains level, parallel to the floor. confirm this by touching both your asis, and noting that they are level with each other. why does your pelvis not fall toward the unsupported side? stand up. now, take one foot off the tas k the gluteus medius and minimus on the supported side contract to keep the pelvis level . results in trendelenburgs sign. when the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis falls away to the contralateral side. when asked to walk, such a patient exhibits trendelenburgs gait. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=he0lk5mvfeg paralysis of the abductors of the hip info

14.4 medial rotators of the thigh 18 previous next minimus extend as far forward as the asis, where you will find the origin of the tensor fascia lata. the anterior portions of the gluteus medius and notice that the origin of the gluteus medius and tas k minimus, therefore, and the tensor fascia lata, pull medially across the anterior aspect of the hip (green arrow). these muscles therefore, along with the tensor fascia lata, are medial rotators of the hip.

14.4 the lateral rotators of the hip inferior to the gluteus medius and minimus are a group of six smaller muscles that pull horizontally across the back of the hip (red arrow). this muscle group is collectively known as the lateral rotators of the hip, and is named according to their common action. immediately posterior and inferior to the gluteus medius and minimus, 19 previous next which passes through the greater sciatic foramen accompanied by important neurovascular structures. identify the piriformis muscle , tas k as its name suggests, it has a wide base, attached to the anterior surface of the sacrum (turn the specimen over to see the origin of the piriformis inside the pelvis), and a tendinous apex, like the stem of a pear, attached to the base of the greater trochanter. nerves and vessels pass through the greater sciatic foramen superior and inferior to the piriformis. because it can be used as a landmark in the identification of nerves, blood vessels and other muscles, the piriformis is referred to as the key to the region.

14.4 nerves of the gluteal region 20 previous next from where it forms, in the pelvis, through the greater sciatic foramen superior to the piriformis. follow it as it runs, like the filling in a sandwich, between the gluteus medius and minimus muscles. the superior gluteal nerve innervates these abductors of the hip, and damage to the identify the superior gluteal nerve (normally with its companion artery and vein) passing tas k identify the inferior gluteal nerve (normally with its companion artery and vein) passing from where it forms, in the pelvis, through the greater sciatic foramen inferior to the piriformis. follow the inferior gluteal nerve to the gluteus maximus, which it innervates. identify the sciatic nerve, the largest nerve in the body . it usually passes through the greater sciatic foramen inferior to the piriformis , and then passes deep to the gluteus maximus muscle into the posterior (hamstring) compartment of the thigh. it and its branches innervate the hamstrings as well as all muscles distal to the knee. moisten the specimen and cover it completely with damp cloths . superior gluteal nerve can cause pelvic instability and trendelenburgs sign / gait.

14.4 info: intramuscular injections 21 previous next the gluteal region is a common site of intramuscular injections because of the size of the muscles in this region. neurovascular intramuscular injections info structures must be avoided in this procedure. by dividing the gluteal region into quadrants, and choosing the superolateral quadrant, neurovascular structures of the region are avoided. landmarks are i) a vertical line through the highest point on the iliac crest (remember that the gluteal region extends as far anteriorly as the asis), and ii) a horizontal line passing through the midpoint between the highest point on the iliac crest and the ischial tuberosity. the anterolateral region of the superolateral quadrant is the safe zone for intramuscular injection, and needles placed here enter the gluteus medius anterosuperior to the gluteus maximus muscle.

14.4 hip flexors 22 previous next from the anterior aspect, identify, within the false pelvis, the iliacus muscle, which originates within the iliac fossa. notice that it is joined, as it passes under return to the prosected thigh. tas k the inguinal ligament, by the psoas muscle, which originates from the lumbar vertebrae. observe that the two muscles insert via a combined tendon, into the lesser trochanter. they form the floor of the femoral triangle. together, they are commonly referred to as the iliopsoas. because they pull vertically across the anterior aspect of the hip joint (green arrow), they are the primary flexors of this joint.

14.4 the thigh the thigh extends roughly between the hip and knee joints. posteriorly, the gluteal fold separates the thigh from the gluteal region. anteriorly, the inguinal ligament separates the thigh from the abdominal wall. the thigh is separated into three compartments by fascial septae that extend from the fascia lata to the femur. these are the i) anterior compartment, which contains muscles that primarily extend the knee joint, ii) posterior compartment, which contains muscles that primarily flex the knee joint, and iii) the medial compartment, which contains muscles that primarily adduct the hip joint. 23 previous next neurovascular access to the thigh is provided by three routes: i) the gap between the inguinal ligament and the pelvic bone connects the abdomen to the anterior compartment of the thigh, ii) the obturator canal connects the pelvis and the medial compartment of the thigh, and iii) the fascial plane deep to the gluteus maximus connects the gluteal region with the posterior compartment of the thigh.

identify, on either side of the rectus femoris the vastus lateralis and the vastus medialis. gently move the rectus femoris aside to see the vastus intermedius. the vasti originate on the femur, and so cross, and act on, only the knee joint. these are the four heads of the quadriceps. they pull vertically across the anterior aspect of the knee joint (green arrow), and are therefore the extensor muscles of the knee . identify the common tendon of the quadriceps, in which the patella develops, and its extension to the tibia, the patellar ligament. notice that the vastus lateralis blends with the quadriceps femoris tendon 14.4 the anterior compartment of the thigh 24 previous next the bulk of the anterior compartment of the thigh. identify, in the midline of the thigh, the rectus femoris. notice that it crosses the anterior aspect of both the hip and knee joints . identify the quadriceps femoris, which occupies tas k from the lateral aspect, and that the vastus medialis blends with the quadriceps femoris tendon from the medial aspect. these muscles stabilize the position of the patella between the femoral condyles. on the anterior aspect of the prosected lower limb,

14.4 the medial compartment of the thigh 25 previous next able to see the medial aspect of the thigh. notice that the muscles of the medial compartment originate from laterally rotate the leg so as to be tas k the pubic bone. follow these muscles to their line of attachment along the length of the linea aspera of the femur. their pull is inferior to the hip joint (green arrow), and they therefore adduct the hip ; in fact, these muscles, as a group are referred to as the adductors of the hip. on the medial aspect of the distal femur, identify a gap called the adductor hiatus in the insertion of the largest adductor, the adductor magnus. vessels pass from the anterior compartment of the thigh to the popliteal fossa through the adductor hiatus.

14.4 the posterior compartment of the thigh 26 previous next the ischial tuberosity via a common tendon. identify, here, the hamstring muscles. note their origin from tas k follow these muscles across the posterior aspect of both the hip and knee joints. note that the tendon of one hamstring muscle, the biceps femoris, crosses the lateral aspect of the knee to attach to the head of the fibula. notice that the tendons of the other two hamstring muscles, the semitendinosus and semimembranosus, cross to the medial aspect of the proximal tibia. these are surface anatomy landmarks that define the superomedial and superolateral borders of the popliteal fossa. because the hamstrings pull vertically across the posterior aspect of the hip and knee (green arrow), they extend the hip and flex the knee. this should be logical to you, and therefore, easy to remember. as you are now finished this exercise, moisten the prosection of the full leg and cover it completely with damp cloths . turn the prosection over to view its posterior aspect.

previous next the fascia lata and the intermuscular septae are composed of inextensible, dense irregular ct. compartment syndrome info compartment syndrome results from increased pressure within a muscular compartment, perhaps due to edema or hemorrhage. the most common cause is trauma, such as fracture. increased pressure impedes blood flow into the compartment, resulting in ischemic pain, and if left untreated, can cause ischemic necrosis of muscle and nerve. 14.4 info: compartment syndrome 27

when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to recognize and describe the: articulations of the spine, including the intervertebral discs, facet joints and ligaments the intervertebral (neural) foramina and spinal canal 14.5 objectives 2 previous next

14.5 introduction in week 39, you will learn about inflammatory back disease. the anatomy of the vertebral column and its articulations is foundational to understanding this pathology. this exercise is a review of selected content initially presented in unit 1, lab 1. adjacent bony vertebrae are joined by articulations, thereby forming the vertebral column. these articulations include the intervertebral discs, which are symphyses, and the zygopophyseal or facet joints, which are synovial joints. the integrity of the vertebral column is reinforced by numerous strong ligaments. 3 previous next

14.5 the vertebral column 4 previous next or the hanging skeleton, ensure that you can identify each of the following vertebral components: body, pedicle, lamina, spinous process, transverse process, superior articular process and inferior articular process. if you need reminding, click here: using the articulated vertebral column provided, tas k intervertebral foramen. do you recall what occupies each of these spaces? differentiate between the vertebral canal and the tas k point to the location of the zygopophyseal joints. name the two articulating elements that meet to form a zygopophyseal joint. if you need reminding, click here: point to the location of the intervertebral discs. tas k

14.5 intervertebral discs each vertebral body is joined to the next by an intervertebral disc which consists of an outer, tough, fibrocartilaginous annulus fibrosus , and a gelatinous core called the nucleus pulposus . the intervertebral disc offers tough, flexible support. the annulus fibrosus anchors the intervertebral disc to the vertebral body. the highly hydrated nucleus pulposis withstands compression and is very deformable, thereby allowing the discs to act as a shock absorbers between vertebrae and permitting flexion , extension and rotation of the vertebral column. 5 previous next sectioned in the midsagittal plane. identify the specimen sectioned through the pedicles, thereby separating the vertebral bodies from the neural arch. on both specimens, identify the intervertebral discs, and on the sagittally-sectioned specimen, identify the annulus fibrosus and nucleus pulposus. unwrap the specimens labelled, articulated vertebrae with ligaments. identify the specimen tas k nucleus pulposus pushes through the annulus fibrosis into the intervertebral foramen, thus compressing a spinal nerve or its root. with age, wear and tear, an intervertebral disc can herniate , such that the info

14.5 zygopophyseal joints the superior and inferior articular processes of adjacent vertebrae are joined by synovial joints called zygopophyseal (facet) joints. the orientation of the zygopophyseal joints varies in different regions of the spinal column and thereby influences the range of movement between adjacent vertebrae around the three possible axes in each of the different regions. 6 previous next joints on the prosected specimens provided, and note their fibrous joint capsules. identify the location of the zygopophyseal tas k

14.5 segmental ligaments of the vertebral column some of the ligaments joining the vertebral column are segmental, extending from one vertebra to the next, while others are continuous, running the length of the vertebral column. 7 previous next 1) the interspinous ligaments, which join the spinous processes of adjacent vertebrae, and 2) the ligamenta flava , which join the laminae of adjacent vertebrae. the ligamenta flava have a particularly high content of elastic fibres, and thus provide more give than most ligaments. find the following segmental ligaments on the wet specimens provided: tas k

14.5 continuous ligaments of the vertebral column 8 previous next find the following continuous ligaments, which run longitudinally along the length of the vertebral column: on the wet specimens provided, tas k 1) the supraspinous ligament, which connects the spinous processes, 2) the posterior longitudinal ligament, a narrow band that connects the posterior aspect of the vertebral bodies and intervertebral discs along the length of the vertebral canal and 3) the anterior longitudinal ligament, a broad band that connects the anterior aspect of the vertebral bodies and intervertebral discs.

14.5 herniated discs 9 previous next because the annulus fibrosus is thinner posteriorly and because the posterior ligament is not as broad as the anterior ligament. as a result, a herniated disc most commonly compresses a spinal nerve or its roots in the intervertebral foramen, rather than the spinal cord itself in the vertebral canal. intervertebral discs tend to herniate posterolaterally info thus, the neural effects of a herniated disc often affect the region of distribution of a single spinal nerve, leaving regions above and below unaffected.

since the start of this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify the components of a typical vertebra: body, pedicle, lamina, spinous process, transverse process, superior articular process and inferior articular process. identify the intervertebral foramen. what emerges from the intervertebral foramen? which articulations of the vertebral column are synovial joints? what are the two component parts of an intervertebral disc? what physical and functional properties does each impart on the intervertebral disc? identify these two component parts on a prosected vertebral column. identify the ligaments of the vertebral column: the interspinous ligaments, ligamenta flava, supraspinous ligament, posterior longitudinal ligament, anterior longitudinal ligament; which are segmental, and which are continuous? how does the anatomy of the anterior and posterior longitudinal ligaments influence the direction of disc herniation? if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, move on to the next exercise, or if its not time to switch, go on a field trip to grants museum of anatomy and review specimens in the upper limb, lower limb, and back sections. 14.5 progress check 10 previous next

lab 14 field trip the specimens in grants museum are organized by body region. the museum section on the upper and lower limb are relevant to lab 14, as are some specimens dissected to show the deep musculature of the back. review them when you have time between exercises. previous
